articles.headline: Federal Reserve Sees Slower Growth, but Maintains Plans to Trim Stimulus
articles.snippet: The central bank will reduce its monthly bond purchases by $10 billion a month and still expects to stop expanding its holdings this year.
articles.abstract: The central bank will reduce its monthly bond purchases by $10 billion a month and still expects to stop expanding its holdings this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Wednesday sharply cut its economic forecast for 2014 even as it said the economy had bounced back after a nasty winter, allowing the central bank, in its view, to continue to retreat from its stimulus campaign.

articles.headline: Fire Phone Immerses Users in Amazon’s World
articles.snippet: If Amazon entices even a fraction of its 250 million customers, it could accelerate already intense competition with retailers and tech companies.
articles.abstract: If Amazon entices even a fraction of its 250 million customers, it could accelerate already intense competition with retailers and tech companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon on Wednesday announced a device that tries to fulfill the retailer’s dream of being integrated into consumers’ lives at every possible waking moment — whether they are deciding where to eat, realizing they need more toilet paper or intrigued by a snatch of overheard music.

articles.headline: Dubai, Once a Humble Refueling Stop, Is Crossroad to the Globe
articles.snippet: Dubai’s rise as a modern crossroads connecting East and West is a tale of globalization, ambition, and an audacious bet on the future of air travel that proved prescient.
articles.abstract: Dubai’s rise as a modern crossroads connecting East and West is a tale of globalization, ambition, and an audacious bet on the future of air travel that proved prescient.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — The gimmicks to attract attention and passengers — a $1 million raffle, a chance to win a Porsche 911, or a monthlong shopping festival — are still there but are hardly needed anymore. Travelers from around the world no longer need to be lured to this parched former trading post on the edge of the Persian Gulf.

articles.headline: TCI Hedge Fund in Britain Ends Ties to Charitable Arm
articles.snippet: According to regulatory filings in Britain, the Children’s Investment Fund, known as TCI, will no longer donate money to the foundation on a contractual basis, though it may do so on a discretionary basis.
articles.abstract: According to regulatory filings in Britain, the Children’s Investment Fund, known as TCI, will no longer donate money to the foundation on a contractual basis, though it may do so on a discretionary basis.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Christopher Hohn, the founder of one of Britain’s largest and most successful hedge funds, chose to structure his fund to automatically donate a portion of its fees to charity — specifically his wife’s charity — people took notice.

articles.headline: Amazon Fire Phone’s Missed Opportunities
articles.snippet: The world needed a great, cheap smartphone, and Amazon seems uniquely capable of delivering such a device. But the Fire instead aims at a saturated high end.
articles.abstract: The world needed a great, cheap smartphone, and Amazon seems uniquely capable of delivering such a device. But the Fire instead aims at a saturated high end.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Amazon invited the media and hundreds of its most loyal customers to witness the unveiling of a new device on Wednesday, everyone thought the company would introduce a smartphone made in the mold of its line of tablet computers: pretty good and really cheap.

articles.headline: Uneasy Alliance Gives Insurgents an Edge in Iraq
articles.snippet: Saddam Hussein’s former loyalists have been crucial in helping Sunni insurgents capture vast amounts of territory so quickly.
articles.abstract: Saddam Hussein’s former loyalists have been crucial in helping Sunni insurgents capture vast amounts of territory so quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — Meeting with the American ambassador some years ago in Baghdad, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki detailed what he believed was the latest threat of a coup orchestrated by former officers of Saddam Hussein’s Baath Party.

articles.headline: As Moderate Islamists Retreat, Extremists Surge Unchecked
articles.snippet: Elected Islamists have been shoved to the margins, and they are debating how to revive the Arab Spring’s dream of synthesizing Islam and democracy.
articles.abstract: Elected Islamists have been shoved to the margins, and they are debating how to revive the Arab Spring’s dream of synthesizing Islam and democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Islamist politicians swept elections across the region in the aftermath of the Arab Spring, stepping close to power in Tunisia, Egypt, Libya and Morocco and undermining the thesis of Qaeda-style militants that violence offered the only hope for change.

articles.headline: Smartphones Embracing ‘Kill Switches’ as Theft Defense
articles.snippet: Since Apple introduced anti-theft technology in September, police in several cities say iPhone thefts have dropped. Now, Google and Microsoft are also adding “kill switches.”
articles.abstract: Since Apple introduced anti-theft technology in September, police in several cities say iPhone thefts have dropped. Now, Google and Microsoft are also adding “kill switches.”
articles.lead_paragraph: By next summer, most new smartphones may no longer be quite so attractive to thieves.

articles.headline: For Dov Charney of American Apparel, an Abrupt Fall From Grace
articles.snippet: After years of negative press, the board of American Apparel ousted Mr. Charney as chairman and chief executive.
articles.abstract: After years of negative press, the board of American Apparel ousted Mr. Charney as chairman and chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dov Charney was no one’s idea of a button-down executive.

articles.headline: Challengers Emerge to Replace Divisive Maliki
articles.snippet: Iraqi leaders, alarmed over the Sunni insurgency, are actively seeking to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki with someone supported by all Iraqi sects.
articles.abstract: Iraqi leaders, alarmed over the Sunni insurgency, are actively seeking to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki with someone supported by all Iraqi sects.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi officials said Thursday that political leaders had started intensive jockeying to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and create a government that would span the country’s deepening sectarian and ethnic divisions, spurred by what they called encouraging meetings with American officials signaling support for a leadership change.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: Why Did Amazon Make a Phone? A Conversation With Jeff Bezos
articles.snippet: Jeffrey P. Bezos, Amazon’s founder and chief executive, discusses his motivation behind making the Fire smartphone, whether he expects to make a profit on the device, and more.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey P. Bezos, Amazon’s founder and chief executive, discusses his motivation behind making the Fire smartphone, whether he expects to make a profit on the device, and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after he introduced the new Fire phone on Wednesday, I spoke with Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s founder and chief executive, about the device and Amazon’s goals in the smartphone business.

articles.headline: U.S. to Send Up to 300 Military Advisers to Iraq
articles.snippet: Ruling out combat forces, President Obama said the United States will send up to 300 advisers to help Iraq repel Sunni militants who have captured several cities.
articles.abstract: Ruling out combat forces, President Obama said the United States will send up to 300 advisers to help Iraq repel Sunni militants who have captured several cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Thursday that he would deploy up to 300 military advisers to Iraq to help its struggling security forces fend off a wave of Sunni militants who have overrun large parts of the country, edging the United States back into a conflict that Mr. Obama once thought he had left behind.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael R. Gordon
